text:
Hello, team!
With this year’s <#C67L30Z3L|jsoc> projects being announced, I’d like to inquire about prospective cooperation – _in a way_, I’d also be glad to commence a kind of <#C767M3VB3|academia> networking.
Out of the JSoC topics under the Turing project, I’ve found the iterative methods for inference in GP especially interesting (not limited to, though) - and having thumbed through some of the related articles, I may just add it is also a :blossom: subject.
On the more personal side, I’ve been searching for a kind of a summer research project and eventually arrived at the idea it would be just amazing to include an element beneficial to the Julia community - particularly as I’ve found Julia incredibly useful for my private projects recently. I’m happy to free the JSoC-funded slots to others right away, yet I’d be glad to couple some folks experienced in the field so that we could aim at a high-quality contribution (potentially turning into a research paper?). I’m a graduate student in pure mathematics (pursuing a master degree) with a keen interest in the applications thereof (also with thorough exposure to numerics, probability theory, computer science, …) with some applied research experience in a big tech company’s lab.
If you think this is not the right place for the post or there are places more appropriate, I’d be sincerely grateful for your suggestions - thank you!

text: Not sure if I am picking that up right, but: Make sure you don’t rule out doing a JSoC too early based on too much second guessing, perhaps it is actually something you might wish to apply when the time comes
